Invocation

Delivered by: Rev. Katrina D. Foster, Pastor, Fordham Evangelical Lutheran Church, 2430 Walton Avenue, Bronx, NY 10468.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Baez.

The Invocation was delivered by: Rev. Katrina D. Foster, Pastor, Fordham Evengelical Lutheran Church, 2430 Walton Avenue, The Bronx, N.Y. 10468.

Council Member Baez moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By the Chair of the Land Use Committee Council Member Katz:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(c) of the Council and Section 197-d(b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the action of the City Planning Commission on Uniform Land Use Procedure Application no. C 080044 PQM, an acquisition, shall be subject to Council review.  This application is related to application no. C 080043 HAM that is subject to Council review pursuant to Section 197-d of the New York City Charter.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: ULURP, 2282-2284 Frederick Douglass Boulevard, Manhattan (C080044PQM)

Items.Title:
By The Speaker (Council Member Quinn):
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 636 Hudson Street, Application no. 20085145 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.

Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 636 Hudson Street, Mahattan (20085145TCM)

Items.Title:
By The Speaker (Council Member Quinn):

Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 196 Eighth Avenue, Manhattan (20085154TCM)

Report of the Committee on Environmental Protection
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the City of New York, in relation to developing and implementing a sustainable stormwater management plan.

Items.MatterName: Developing and implementing a sustainable stormwater management plan.

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Finance

Resolution calling upon the State of New York to end the real property tax exemption granted to Madison Square Garden (“MSG” or the “Garden”) so that the revenue raised from putting MSG back on the City’s property tax rolls can be used to provide City services or tax relief to City residents.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Finance
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: 
Council Members Arroyo, Koppell, and Rivera.

The following 5 Council Members formally abstained from voting on this item: 
Council Members Dilan, Foster, James, Martinez, and Vacca.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: NYS to end the real property tax exemption granted to Madison Square Garden ("MSG" or the "Garden").

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York in relation to prohibiting objects containing glass packaging or containers on or within 150 feet of a beach owned by the City of New York.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting objects containing glass packaging or containers on or within 150 feet of a beach owned by the City of New York.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring specific experience based qualifications for candidates nominated for appointment to serve on the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: Requiring specific experience based qualifications for candidates nominated for appointment to serve on the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

Items.Title: Resolution amending Resolution No. 538 (L.U. 197-A) adopted by the Council on September 27, 2006.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: Amending Resolution No. 538 (L.U. 197-A) adopted by the Council on September 27, 2006.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to reclassify Medgar Evers College as a four-year post-secondary institution for capital budget purposes.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Higher Education
Items.MatterName: Reclassify Medgar Evers College as a four-year post-secondary institution for capital budget purposes.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon Congress to pass H.R. 2419, the Farm, Nutrition, and Bioenergy Act of 2007, which will increase the minimum food stamp grant, and the president to sign it into law.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass H.R. 2419, the Farm, Nutrition, and Bioenergy Act of 2007.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to adopt a Subway Riders Bill of Rights.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: MTA to adopt a Subway Riders Bill of Rights.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Department of City Planning to commence immediately a downzoning study of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn and upon the Department of Buildings to implement the appropriate procedure so as to not issue permits that would allow any new construction or alteration to an existing building that would exceed a height limit of 50 feet until the Carroll Gardens neighborhood downzoning is complete.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: Commence immediately a downzoning study of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

Items.Title: Resolution declaring the first week of October as “Arts Advocacy Week in Harlem.”
Items.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries & International Intergroup Relations
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MatterName: Declaring the first week of October as “Arts Advocacy Week in Harlem.”

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring agency budgets and service statements to be published and filed electronically.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Requiring agency budgets and service statements to be published and filed electronically.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to repaving streets.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Repaving Streets

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York, the New York City Department of Transportation and the New York City Bureau of Traffic Enforcement to significantly increase fines and step up enforcement efforts for all traffic violations within the central business district of Manhattan in order to deter violators and help to effectively relieve traffic congestion and reduce air pollution.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Significantly increase fines and step up enforcement efforts for all traffic violations within the central business district of Manhattan.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York, the New York City Department of Transportation and the New York City Planning Commission to increase the number of commercial loading zones within the central business district of Manhattan and to lawfully require off-street loading docks to be built when any new commercial buildings are constructed or substantially renovated within the central business district of Manhattan.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Increase the number of commercial loading zones within the central business district of Manhattan.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to impose two-way tolls for trucks on all crossings into and out of the City that are under its control for the purposes of removing the incentives for trucks to travel unnecessarily through the central business district of Manhattan to avoid the payment of tolls.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to impose two-way tolls for trucks on all crossings into and out of the City that are under its control.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York and the New York City Department of Transportation to increase the number of metered parking spots within the non-residential areas of the central business district of Manhattan while also modestly increasing the rate of metered parking within the central business district of Manhattan.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: DOT to increase the number of metered parking spots within the non-residential areas of the central business district of Manhattan,

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to enact a one-third of one percent (.33%) payroll tax, to be imposed on businesses within the City of New York and within the surrounding counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland, and to create a regional authority to administer this revenue, which would be dedicated to improving and maintaining subways, commuter rails, highways, bridges and tunnels within the greater New York City region.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: State Legislature to enact a one-third of one percent (.33%) payroll tax, to be imposed on businesses within NYC and within the surrounding counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to fully explore adopting legislation and/or regulatory measures to incentivize the immediate marketing and use of hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, to develop the re-fueling infrastructure to support these vehicles and to consider making the manufacture and importation of gasoline combustion vehicles unlawful by a date certain; and calling upon the city of New York to take steps to advance the use of hydrogen fuel cell technology and to find ways to  promote New York City as an economic center for hydrogen fuel cell technology.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Explore adopting legislation and/or regulatory measures to incentivize the immediate marketing and use of hydrogen fuel cell vehicles.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York, the New York City Department of Transportation and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to approve and institute a plan for the construction of a Trans-Narrows Tunnel between the boroughs of Brooklyn and Staten Island for the purposes of connecting the Staten Island railway to the New York City subway system.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: DOT and the MTA to approve and institute a plan for the construction of a Trans-Narrows Tunnel between the boroughs of Brooklyn and Staten Island.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York, the New York State Department of Transportation and the New York City Department of Transportation to approve and institute a plan for the construction of a Gowanus Expressway Tunnel to replace the elevated Gowanus Expressway.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: NYS DOT and the NYC DOT to approve and institute a plan for the construction of a Gowanus Expressway Tunnel.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Federal government to approve and institute a plan for the construction of the Cross Harbor Freight Tunnel.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Approve and institute a plan for the construction of the Cross Harbor Freight Tunnel.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York to relocate those City agencies that do not need to be in the central business district of Manhattan to outer borough neighborhoods that are near train lines with available capacity during rush hours.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Relocate those City agencies that do not need to be in the central business district of Manhattan to outer borough neighborhoods.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York, the New York City Department of Transportation, and the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission to significantly increase the number of taxi stands within the central business district of Manhattan and to equip such stands with all-weather furniture and shelter that would attract passengers to use such stands.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: DOT and TLC to significantly increase the number of taxi stands within the central business district of Manhattan.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to amend the Federal Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and implement regulations to increase the maximum eligible age for services to 24 years old from under 22 years old and to recognize the unique needs of LGBTQ runaway and homeless youth; and calling upon the New York State Legislature to amend the State Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and implement regulations to increase the maximum eligible age for services to 24 years old from 21 years old, to recognize the unique needs of LGBTQ runaway and homeless youth, specifically by allowing, where appropriate, settings that are not gender segregated, to allow the maximum length of stay for youth in transitional independent living programs to be calculated independently of their 21st birthdays, to ease the 24-hour staffing requirement for residential programs, and to provide start-up grants for State certification applicants to use during the certification waiting period.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Youth Services
Items.MatterName: State Legislature to amend the federal and State runaway and homeless youth acts.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel in diesel-powered generators used in the production of films, television programs and advertisements, and at street fairs in New York City.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Use of ultra low sulfur diesel fuel in diesel-powered generators used in the production of films, television programs and advertisements, and at street fairs in NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to providing legal counsel for certain persons subject to eviction or foreclosure proceedings.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Providing legal counsel for certain persons subject to eviction or foreclosure proceedings.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring an annual report from the department of citywide administrative services detailing the status of unused city-owned real property.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Requiring an annual report from the department of citywide administrative services detailing the status of unused city-owned real property.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to regulating construction operations occurring near landmarks.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Regulating construction operations occurring near landmarks.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the City of New York, in relation to the human rights law.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Rights
Items.MatterName: Human Rights Law (protected class; affirmatively further fair housing)

Items.Title: Resolution supporting the Bloomberg Administration’s Lower Manhattan Security Initiative and its expansion of New York City surveillance cameras.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Supporting the Bloomberg Administration’s Lower Manhattan Security Initiative and its expansion of New York City surveillance cameras.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to dismissing notices of violations issued to motor vehicles parked in front of illegal curb cuts.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Dismissing notices of violations issued to motor vehicles parked in front of illegal curb cuts.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the registration of general contractors.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Registration of general contractors.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring certain buildings or structures to undergo a structural inspection.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Requiring any building or structure that has been vacant for three years or longer to be inspected prior to the issuance of any permit to alter, repair, remove or enlarge that building or structure.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the Governor of New York State and the New York State Legislature to adopt the recommendations of the Commission on the Future of Indigent Defense Services.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Criminal Justice Services
Items.MatterName: State Legislature to adopt the recommendations of the Commission on the Future of Indigent Defense Services.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to permissible parking for certain purposes.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Permissible parking for certain purposes.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the New York city department of education to provide voter registration forms to all eighteen year old students.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Requiring the New York city department of education to provide voter registration forms to all eighteen year old students.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the New York State Senate to pass S. 3930, S. 3931, S. 3932 and S. 3933, which would protect the voting rights of the people of New York.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Protect the voting rights of the people of New York. (S.3930, S.3931, S.3932 and S.3933)

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision of services to people living with HIV and AIDS.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Provision of services to people living with HIV and AIDS.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to enact A.2140/S.1312, an act to amend the education law in relation to allowing immunizing agents to be administered to adults by pharmacists.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Amend the education law in relation to allowing immunizing agents to be administered to adults by pharmacists.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Legislature of the State of New York to amend New York State Public Officers Law to require that a person seeking municipal elective office in the City of New York be a resident of the political subdivision in which he/she is seeking election at least one year immediately preceding the election.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Require that a person seeking municipal elective office in NYC be a resident of the political subdivision in which he/she is seeking election at least one year immediately preceding the election.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring that the Department for the Aging fingerprint all employees at City senior centers for the purposes of conducting background investigations.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging
Items.MatterName: Requiring that the Department for the Aging fingerprint all employees at City senior centers for the purpose of conducting background investigations.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Department of Education (DOE) to institute a policy that would limit the aggregate amount of homework that is given to elementary and middle grade school children to approximately ten minutes per grade level on any given night, and would include a homework-free night to allow children to participate in other activities, exercise and spend quality time with their families.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Dep't of Education to institute a policy that would limit the aggregate amount of homework that is given to elementary and middle grade school children to approximately ten minutes per grade level on any given night.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Legislature of the State of New York to amend the New York State Racing, Pari-Mutuel Wagering and Breeding Law to reduce State-imposed financial mandates on off-track betting corporations which have recently been absorbing a growing portion of the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation’s revenues, driving the corporation into insolvency, and yielding no residual revenues for the city of New York.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Amend the New York State Racing, Pari-Mutuel Wagering and Breeding Law.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to introduce and adopt, and the Governor to sign, legislation which would authorize the city of New York to provide a personal income tax credit to residential homeowners who switch from oil to natural gas to heat their homes.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Authorize NYC  to provide a personal income tax credit to residential homeowners who switch from oil to natural gas to heat their homes.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the registration of vacant buildings and lots.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Registration of vacant buildings and lots.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to an annual survey of vacant and abandoned properties.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: An annual survey of vacant and abandoned properties.
